title: Well would you look at that? NOW everyone thinks Ryze is OP
body:
Douches be like:

**When Ryze just got reworked:**

Wtf Riot, now his Q sucks....
I cant build tanky anymore.........
Ryze rework is a failure.....
Ryze just got Veigar'ed

**When Ryze got played in LCS:**

Omg 2+ snares in 5 seconds?
Wow, he's so damn OP!
So much spam, fking OP......
Riot, pls nerf Ryze...

This actually defines most of League Boards Community. It's kinds like this that I feel like bitchslapping so much.

It's always been like this. People never even bothered to test out the reworked abilities of a certain champion because **they were too scared**, and most specifically, it's kind of like a "I dont play Ryze a lot because my mom( FNC Huni, no offence bro :p ) doesnt". Now, it's all "Oh look, my mom rocks with Ryze! I should too!". 

My advice?

**Stop making yourself look as stupid as this, and learn the reworked champion's hidden OP-ness yourself, not until your mom says so.**

Who knows, maybe LCS will play Q-reworked Veigar one day, and you'll just become the more obedient spoiled child and follow as usual.

My explanation:

every Ryze worth their salt skilled RQWE. His reworked really did not change his playstyle except give him a window of extremely powerful gameplay instead of the same gameplay weaker all the time. His Q also gains the most damage per rank still. So people still skilled him exactly the same and failed.

What did LCS do differently? Maxed W first. You could always spam so many roots with him in lane but it didn't matter because it was only 0.75 seconds. Now it's ranked up to 1.5 and you can't move while Ryze keeps being Ryze. So yeah. All it took was breaking the skill pattern that has been set in stone for roughly 3 seasons.

Maxing Q is generally a bad idea unless you are _very_ confident in your ability to land it consistently.  Maxing W against lanes that counter you harshly (champs that are really good at all-inning) or maxing E versus the others is generally the way to go.

It is precisely the fact that people did not realize that maxing his other abilities was a better idea and instead chose to not adapt to the way the champion now works is the sole reason for why they thought he sucked

I always have to explain to my friends that if they want to break the meta, they have to understand the meta they're breaking. Instead, sometimes they like to just parrot things other people have done or said without much actual experience on the matter. Yes, in theory that kill lane could work, but if they have plenty of disengage, then it's a safe bet that the kill lane will not get the net gain you're hoping for. Same for the off-meta jungler: If he doesn't have an extreme strength, then he may not have enough to take advantage of to make up for his weaknesses. Then there's the sudden lane switches I sometimes see. But they only work if both people can handle the lane they're walking into. More than once I've seen someone losing a lane slowly ask to be switched, only for the person they brought in next to lose even faster because their champion isn't meant to handle it. 

Knowledge and experience are much more valuable than hearsay and theorycrafting.

I've played Ryze about 10 times the first day he was reworked, I watched the LCS game, and I still think Ryze is worse off.

I played him because of his builds, his strong late game, but most importantly, because he had targeted damage which countered mobility really hard especially early game.

His reworked Q stinks. The visual is further than the hitbox actually is. Yes you can now scout with it which is fine, but he is countered more now by champions he used to do fine against.

My biggest annoyance is his passive. You need to ramp up your passive...that's fine. But then when it's peaks, you lose it after 4 - 6 seconds?............................... You lose so much time in a team fight with it down, that you barely get to enjoy it while he's in steroid mode. 

Not saying that he's bad, but I really can't stand his new playstyle.

Also Veigar only saw competitive play for his stun. There's no reason a team would pick him now. He's not a safe choice and his playmaking is very limited.

I always though Ryze was a little op, but I'm fairly sure that was just me being salty when he snares me, bursts me, and then snares me again as I try to flee.

Too be fair....I did say that Ryze didn't need further buffs after his rework as his damage was incredibly high and very strong and that it was people assuming that he sucked and not adapting their playstyle which is why everyone thought he was weak.

But sadly, people are sheep and once they have heard that something "sucks" or see a significant change (such as his Q becoming a skillshot) they will rapidly jump to conclusions that the champ is ruined and wont even attempt to change their playstyle.

For example, on average any game I play as Ryze I max my E before my Q (honestly there is no reason to max Q before anything other than just getting more damage out of it), and the reason I max my E is because the amount of damage that skill dishes out is downright crazy.  It pretty much zones any melee laner that isn't tanky or doesn't have sustain.  It is also very strong against ranged champions as it forces them to avoid their own minions or take a pretty massive amount of damage.  This of course either zones the champ away from farm (in the case of melee champs) or forces them to (in most cases) not be able to use their minions as a shield from my Qs if they want to farm.
